EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant in their cold storage facility in Royal Oaks, California.  It is Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC.A?s policy to comply with all applicable governmental regulations.  Further, it is Marinovich's objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities.



Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. emphasizes safe and environmentally sound operating practices and procedures through their employee training programs.  In addition to job specific training, operators and maintenance personnel receive training in accident prevention, safety, and first aid.  Additionally, an emergency action/response plan has been prepared for Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.



Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. has developed a detailed Compliance Audit Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with Process Safety Management (PSM) and 40 CFR Part 68 (RMP regulations).  At least every three years, Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. audits these programs and any findings of noncompliance are documented and responded to and the deficiencies are corrected.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. owns and operates a cold storage facility located at 303A Salinas Road in Royal Oaks, California.  There are two refrigeration systems currently at the facility, the original (or main) refrigeration system (Process 1) and a second system based in engine room #2.  The original refrigeration system was installed in 1946.  The second refrigeration system (Process 2) (based in engine room #2) was installed in 1970.  Both refrigeration systems have been upgraded and modernized several times over the years. Process 2 was pumped down, vacated, isolated and not in operation sin

ce June of 2019.



In both of the refrigeration systems at Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC., anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant that provides process cooling for the cold storage facilities.  Although the systems can operate independently, it is possible to shut down engine room #2. Which has benn done. Currently Marinovich operates the cold storage rooms serviced by engine room #2 from the main refrigeration system.  



During normal operation, anhydrous ammonia is distributed throughout the refrigeration system.  However, during major maintenance activities, portions of the refrigeration system can be pumped down to evacuate the ammonia from the system and store it in the control pressure receiver.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the control pressure receiver in the original (main) refrigeration system at a safe level of 80% by volume is 4,881 pounds

For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, the RMP regulations define the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, has been developed at Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.

An initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.

Written operating procedures have been developed and implemented, and are reviewed at least annually.

Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility have been developed and implemented.

Eac

h employee involved in operating the ammonia system has received initial training and refresher training at least every three years.

Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.

A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.

Pre-startup safety reviews are performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

Audits are conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the CalARP regulations.

Incident investigation procedures have been established.

 A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.

Hot work permits are issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system, when required. System entry/line break permits are issued for all maintenance operations which require opening the system. 

A Contractor Safety Program has been developed and implemented.

To ensure that the general accidental release prevention program and the chemical-specific prevention steps are implemented at Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC., the owner has accepted the overall responsibility for the RMP.  The owner has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements.



Five-Year Accident History

Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. has not had any reportable accidental releases from the ammonia-based refrigeration system that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program

Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. has established an emergency action plan and a chain of command to respond to emergencies and to notify emergency responders when there is a nee

d for a response.  In California the Office of PSM Compliance has stated it is now mandatory that a PSM facility have an Emergency Response Plan.  

In the past Marinovich was by the local AA that an emergency response program does not need to be developed for the facility since Marinovich Cooling and Storage LLC. employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.



Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Update the Emergency Action Plan to an Emergency Response Plan and provide the required equipment and training.

Close up the open wall in the engine room.

Install tight fitting man doors with panic bars.

Add instrumentation and safety calibration and testing to the Maintenance Program.

Add additional lighting to the engine room.

Update P&ID's to a better to understand format.

Label all piping per IIAR and tag all valves.
